276.author: Victor McNeil
276.bottom_line: Wind slabs will be your primary avalanche problem to avoid in all of our zones into the early part of the week.  Moderate winds, primarily out of the West, with localized strong gusts have built fresh wind slabs on leeward aspects (E, NE, NW) near and above treeline.   At lower elevations new storm snow and wind slabs are sitting on a rain crust from 1/12, with weak sugar snow sitting above it.  This is a bad avalanche sandwich, so dig down to see if you can find this weak interface.
276.hazard_discussion: With plenty of snow available for transport, fresh wind slabs will be found near and above the treeline.  Wind slabs generally need a couple of days to bond, so avoid wind loaded terrain >30 degrees today.  If you observe shooting cracks, visually observe cornices, wind pillows, or dune-like formations in the snow, you're looking at wind transported or affected snow.  A wind slab has the ability to grab you off ridgelines and push you into nasty terrain features.  Check out this video of Matt Entz (pro snowmobiler) who recently had a near-miss with a windslab in Colorado.  Triggering a wind slab could have much greater consequences in the Northern Wallowas, if you influence the weak snow found at the bottom of the snowpack.   Also, check out a local observation from the Southern Wallowas here.

media.caption: Southern Wallowas East Aspect 6,800' on 2/6/21.  The classic portrayal of the Persistent Slab avalanche problem.  Here Towner and company found the 1/12 rain crust, with weak sugar snow above it, and a slab above that.  All that's waiting here is a trigger.  You may not find this rain crust at upper elevations, so do some digging to assess before committing to steep slopes > 30 degrees.
